result.execSummary:
The defendant Marquise L Summers was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery [Modifiers: Use Dangerous Weapon (Misdemeanor)], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).
  • Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

timeConds.notes:
On 10/5/16:

Court grants the request of the Department and impose conditional jail of 4 months, with work release/huber privileges to be served in Jefferson County Jail,Court allows the transfer of the conditional jail term to Wood County only if probation can be transfered to Wood County and conditioned that electronic monitoring not be utilized.

Defendant is required to report for commencement and service of jail sentence with absolute sobriety and without non-prescribed controlled substances in his/her system.  Non-compliance will result in loss of Huber/work-release privileges without further process.

Court finds that the defendant has 22 days credit towards the 4 months conditional jail.

Case called at 1:16 pm [sf]
Defendant Marquise L Summers in court. ADA Monica J. Hall appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Agent Castillo appears by telephone for the Department of Corrections.

Court reviews that case was set based on a memo from the Agent requesting a sanction for non-compliance with probation conditions.
Agent Castillo presents additional information for the Court to considered.
ADA Hall presents argument in support of conditional jail time.
Defendant presents statement.
Court inquires of the defendant if he contacted the public defender for representation for todays hearing, Defendant advises that he didn't think he had to apply and thought that one would be here today.

Court grants the request of the Department and impose conditional jail of 4 months, with work release/huber privileges to be served in Jefferson County Jail, Court allows the transfer of the conditional jail term to Wood County only if probation can be transfered to Wood County and conditioned that electronic monitoring not be utilized.

Court finds that the defendant has 22 days credit towards the 4 months conditional jail.
recess:1:27 pm

Case called at 9:50am.  Clerk - CRHI.
Defendant Marquise L Summers not in court.  Theresa A Beck appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Court reviews case history, status and filings. Noting that almost nothing has been paid during the last two years. 
Statment presented by the State. 
Court finds that the defendant has not made a good faith effort to discharge the financial obligations ordered. 
Court extends probation for two years; presents basis. 
Court continues the case for a Review Hearing in approx. 4 months.  By Sept. 2nd, 2016 the Probation Agent shall notify the Def., Court and State of all payments made by the defendant and applied towards restitution and costs. At the Review Hearing, the Court will consider imposing some additional conditional jail time if reasonable payments have not been made.  The Review Hearing will be adjourned by the Court if the information provided by the Probation Agent shows that reasonable payments are being made.
State to submit a proposed order extending probation. 
Recess 9:58am

[Clerk: MK]
case called at 10:25pm. 
Defendant Marquise L Summers in court with Attorney Joanne M Keane.  ADA Theresa Beck appears for the State of Wisconsin.  

On Joint Motion of the parties, the Court amends the single charge to two misdemeanor counts:  
--Count #1:  Misdemeanor Battery While Using a Dangerous Weapon, contrary to Statutes 940.19(1) & 939.63(1)(a)
--Count #2:  Misdemeanor Disorderly Conduct contrary to Statute 947.01(1).

Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights given; plea of " No Contest  " entered on Count #1 and plea of "Guilty" entered on Count #2; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified (ADA Beck submits a packet of restitution information); the Court accepts the pleas, finds Mr. Summers guilty of both counts, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

On both Count #1 and Count #2, the Court withholds sentence, and places Mr. Summers on Probation for two years, with conditions:

--to undergo AODA assessment and comply with treatment recommendations
--to undergo any other assessment, treatment, and counseling as required by the Agent
--to maintain absolute sobriety: no possession or consumption of alcohol; no possession or consumption of non-prescribed controlled substances
--no presence in bars, taverns, liquor stores
--to comply with any monthly testing for drugs or alcohol, as required by the Agent 
--no contact with Zachery Shearier
--to pay restitution of $263 to Radiology Waukesha SC, PO 44269 in Madison, WI537444 ; and to pay restitution of $4653.19 to UW Health Partners/ Watertown Regional Medical Center, 125 Hospital Drive, Watertown, WI 53098 ;   if these amounts have already been paid by Zachery Shearier, or by his parents or by his insurer on Mr. Shearier's behalf, then the restitution payment is to used to reimburse Mr. Shearier or his parents or his insurer
--to pay the 10% restitution processing fee on the restitution amounts 
--to obtain/maintain fulltime employment and/or education program as directed by the Agent
--to pay costs of $243 plus $200 DNA surcharge on each count ($886 total) 

Days credit for time already served:  0  days
The Court indicates that if the DNA surcharge is found to be unconstitutional, and the Defendant has not yet paid the surcharge, then the Judgment of Conviction is to be amended to remove the surcharge payment requirement.  If the DNA surcharge has been paid and the ruling that found the DNA surcharge unconstitutional directs the clerks to reimburse the amount paid, then the clerk is to refund the amount paid to the Defendant. If the reimbursement is not mandated, then the amount will be kept.

The Court indicates that if Mr. Summers successfully completes the Probation term (statutory definition applies) this record is to be expunged.  The Court clarifies to Mr. Summers that he will need to file a petition for expungement when his Probation term concludes.
recess 10:48am.
